registration_responses.q6.question:
2(2x2) factorial repeated measures within-subjects design: Aspect (perfective vs. imperfective) x PP type (instrument vs. location)

To test for between experiment differences, we’ll also include Experiment as a between-subject variable in the eye-tracking analysis.

Example critical item 

Cond.	Aspect	PP type	        Example Sentence	                                           Aspect PP
a	imperfective	location	        Das Mädchen schrieb zurzeit in der Schule	   Match
b	imperfective	instrument	Das Mädchen schrieb zurzeit mit dem Füller	   Mismatch
c	perfective	location	        Das Mädchen schrieb kürzlich in der Schule	   Mismatch
d	perfective	instrument	Das Mädchen schrieb kürzlich mit dem Füller   Match

Critical regions: verb (e.g., schrieb, transl.: ‘wrote’), aspectual marker (e.g., imperfect: zurzeit, transl.: ‘currently’ / perfect: kürzlich, transl.: ‘recently’), verb+aspectual marker, PP region (e.g., location: in der Schule, transl.: ‘at the school’ / instrument: mit dem Füller, transl.: ‘with the fountain pen’)

ONLINE TASK:  look and listen
ONLINE MEASURE(S): eye-tracking
POST-TRIAL TASKS: none
POST-TRIAL MEASURE(S): none
POST-EXPERIMENT TASK: Participants will be presented with all items (and half of the fillers) again. They will see the exact picture quadruplets they encountered in the eye-tracking experiment. The critical sentence will be presented in text below the pictures. The critical sentence they heard in the experiment will be presented up to the aspect marker (e.g., Das Mädchen spielte gerade/kürzlich…, transl.: ‘The girl played currently/recently…’). Their task is to choose the picture that completes the sentence they heard in the experiment (cf., Abashidze et al, 2019; Kreysa et al., 2018 for similar completion tasks).
POST-EXPERIMENT MEASURES: Reaction times from picture display onset to button press to correct choices and choice accuracy.
registration_responses.q10.question: We will test German participants who have not learned a second language before age 6 between 18 and 31 years of age. All participants will be right-handed (self-reported). Participants must have normal or corrected-to normal vision and normal hearing. Participants will be recruited via the linguistics department’s participant pool and will be tested in the eye-tracking lab of the psycholinguistic group at HU Berlin. One experimental session will take approximately 70 minutes, participants will be payed 11€ for taking part in the experiment.
registration_responses.q14.question:
The study is a 2x(2x2) design. The independent variables are
Within-experiment:
1. Aspect (perfective vs. imperfective)
2. PP type (location PP vs. instrument PP)

Between-experiment:
3. Experiment (Experiment 1 vs. experiment 2)
registration_responses.q15.question:
Our dependent variables are

1. log probability ratio of fixations to the critical location picture over fixations to the critical instrument picture in four pre-defined word regions: verb, aspect marker, verb+aspect marker, PP region
2. reaction times to the post-experiment task from the onset of the visual display until a response was made
3. accuracy to the post-experiment task
registration_responses.q17.question:
Within-experiment:
We will run mixed effects models using the lmer-function in R on log ratio of fixations to location vs. instrument for each defined word region. For the RT analyses, we will run mixed effects models on log transformed RT times. In the RT analysis, only correctly answered trials will be included and outliers 2.5*SD above condition mean will be excluded. For accuracy analyses generalized linear mixed models (the glmer-function in R) will be used, since the data has a bimodal distribution.
We will start model selection with the maximally specified mode including random intercepts for participants and items and random slopes for aspect and PP type.
Random effect structure reduction will follow Bates et al. (2015) to obtain the most parsimonious (and not the maximal) model, i.e., the model that best supports the data (instead of the maximal - but often overfitted - model possible).

Eye-tracking: 
Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for PP region: log_ratio~aspect*PP_type (1+aspect*PP_type|subject)+(1+aspect*PP_type|item)

Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for aspect region:
log_ratio~aspect (1+aspect |subject)+(1+aspect |item)

Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for verb region:
log_ratio~1 (1 |subject)+(1 |item)

Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for verb+aspect region:
log_ratio~aspect (1+aspect |subject)+(1+aspect |item)

Maximal model for RT analysis: 
ln_RT~aspect*PP_type (1+aspect*PP_type|subject)+(1+aspect*PP_type|item)

Maximal model for Accuracy analysis: 
Acc~aspect*PP_type (1+aspect*PP_type|subject)+(1+aspect*PP_type|item)

Between-experiment:
In order to compare tasks effects on the real-time data, we’ll additionally include experiment (1 vs. 2) as a between-experiment variable in the analysis. 

Maximal model including experiment as a factor with fully specified random effect structure for PP region: 
log_ratio~experiment*aspect*PP_type (1+aspect*PP_type|subject)+(1+ experiment*aspect*PP_type|item)

Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for aspect region:
log_ratio~ experiment*aspect (1+aspect |subject)+(1+ experiment*aspect |item)

Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for verb region:
log_ratio~ experiment* (1 |subject)+(1+ experiment|item)

Maximal model with fully specified random effect structure for verb+aspect region:
log_ratio~ experiment*aspect (1+aspect |subject)+(1+ experiment*aspect |item)


Starting with the maximal model, the fit of the model will be improved step by step by reducing the random effect structure. Random effect structure reduction is done with REML=FALSE. Random effect structure reduction will be done by assessing the variance each of the random slopes captures in the model (using VarCorr(model) and summary(rePCA(model)). If a variance component does not capture any (meaningful) variance, it will be removed from the model. The random effect structure will be reduced until the model converges and all variance components capture variance explained by the model. This is the most parsimonious (in contrast to the maximal and often overfitted) model (see Bates et al., 2015). We will not look at the fixed effects before the most parsimonious model has been obtained. If two (or more) models converge and seem to capture the variance equally well, the models will be compared using the anova (model1, model2) function to determine which model provides the better fit for the data. When the model that best fits the data is found, REML is set to TRUE for more precise parameter estimation in that model and only then will we look at the fixed effects using summary(model). The fixed effects part of the model remains unchanged.

attributes.title: Creativity & Health
attributes.description: Creativity as mitigating factor for the psychological discomfort related to the COVID-19 outbreak

q1.value: Sergio Agnoli, Serena Mastria, Anita D'Anselmo, Roni Reiter-Palmon, Maciej Karwowski, Nathalie Bonnardel, Todd Lubart, Fabien Girandola, Eric Bonetto, Zorana Ivcevic, James C. Kaufman, GIOVANNI EMANUELE CORAZZA

q2.value:
In the present study we are testing a specific model of hypotheses (see Figure in Analysis Plan), which will be analysed through a structural equation model approach.
- In particular, as demonstrated by recent research, we can expect that the increase of the exposure to COVID-19 might enhance the degree of psychological discomfort (Gao et al., 2020; Lai et al., 2020).
- Along with the exposure to COVID-19, we expect that personality, particularly the stability huge trait (defined by neuroticism, agreeableness, and conscientiousness) will be negatively associated with the degree of mental suffering (Kotov et al., 2010).
- At the same time, according to past research, we can expect that the plasticity huge trait (defined by openness and extraversion) can predict creative self-beliefs (Karwowski & Leduda, 2016).
- Finally, we hypothesize that creative self-beliefs will be negatively associated with the degree of mental suffering both directly and indirectly via a mediation effect on creative performance.
- The ability of seeing alternative answers in the search of an original and effective solution to open problems (measured through the divergent thinking task, Realistic Problems) could therefore be predicted by creative self-beliefs and impact on the mental health outcomes by reducing the mental suffering associated to the COVID-19 outcome.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In the present study, involving participants over different European countries (Italy, France, and Poland) and the United States, mental health outcomes are measured in terms of distress and depression symptoms emerging as a consequence of the exposure to coronavirus events (such as the number of infections and deaths in the residence region, number of acquaintances suffering from COVID-19, number of family members suffering from COVID-19, number of contacts with people affected from COVID-19, etc, - See Variables Section). Creative performance is measured here in terms of originality and fluency in a classical divergent thinking (DT) task, the Realistic Problem task (Runco, Illies, & Eisenman, 2005), which measured DT abilities in a series of realistic situations from the natural environment. Specifically, for the present study two problems related to the everyday life are used and two problems specifically referring to the COVID-19 situation. The context manipulation (everyday vs. COVID-19) of the problems allows us to explore the creative performance as a function of the specific stressful condition associated to the COVID-19. Creative self-beliefs are measured through the Short Scale of Creative Scale (Karwowski et al., 2012), measuring creative self-efficacy and creative identity. Finally, we take into account the predictive effect of personality, which can predict both creativity (Karwowski & Lebuda, 2016; Feist, 1998) and mental health outcomes (Kotov et al., 2010). 

The study will be conducting as an observational study via a survey created through the online PsyToolkit platform (Stoet, 2010, 2017). Using institutional channels (University websites) and social networks, the online link to the study will be spread in order to recruit volunteers. The online procedure has a total duration of around 20 minutes. After the initial written informed consent, participants will complete four blocks of tasks composed by: 1) two realistic problems (one general and one COVID-related problem), 2) two questionnaires (SSCS scale and PHQ-9 scale), 3) two realistic problems (one general and one COVID-related problem), 4) two questionnaires (TIPI, IES-R). Within each block the order of the tasks/questionnaires will be fully randomized across participants. Finally, a series of demographic questions (gender, age, nation, region, education level, type of work) along with questions asking for exposure to COVID-19 (see variables section) are included.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The study will be conducting using the online PsyToolkit platform (Stoet, 2010, 2017). Using institutional channels (University websites) and social networks, the online link to the study will be spread in order to recruit volunteers (recruiting participants from the age of 18 years).

Around 600 participants are planned to be involved in the study. Participants completing less than 80% of the online study will be excluded from the data analysis. Moreover, participants reporting current or past neurological or psychopathological problems will be excluded from the study.

We have set up the study in PsyToolKit and because of the exceptionality of the situation related to the COVID-19 emergence we intend to begin the study promptly. We anticipate that data collection will take approximately two weeks since several authors will collect data simultaneously over different countries in Europe and the United States. The scoring of the data would take around three weeks as well as data analysis would take approximately three weeks/one month.

q11.value: Around 600 participants are planned to be involved in the study.

q12.value: Considering that SEM-models are large sample techniques (Kline, 2015), in order to test the proposed model, we adopt the Jackson’s (2003) indications, suggesting a sample-size to parameters ratio of 20:1 or at least 10:1 (as depicted in the Figure included in the Analysis Plan, our model is specified by 21 parameters). Specifically, around 600 participants are planned to be involved in the study. This slight oversampling method will allow to counteract the possible exclusion of participants.

question.value:
- Exposure to COVID-19.
Exposure to COVID-19 will be scored as a sum (ranging from 3 to 12) of the following variables: number of infected persons in participant’s state/region at the moment of the participation in the study (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high taking into account the national average); number of contacts outside of with whom participant was currently quarantining in the last 14 days (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high); frequency of contacts with persons affected from Coronavirus in the last 14 days (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high); acquaintances affected by Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes); relatives affected by Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes); death among persons the participant know due to Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes).

In the following the items and scales for this variable:

How much contact in person have you had outside of with whom you are currently quarantining in the last 14 days (4 options)?
1. None
2. On one or two occasions
3. About once a week
4. About once a day

How frequently have you come into contact in person with someone with a Coronavirus diagnosis in the last 14 days (5 options)?
1.	Never
2.	Rarely
3.	About once a week
4.	Several times a week
5.	Every day

Had been Coronavirus diagnosed in people you know (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No

Had been Coronavirus diagnosed in a family member (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No

Have you lost anyone you know to Coronavirus (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No


- Divergent thinking performance: Realistic Problems.
Creative performance is scored through a classical divergent thinking task: realistic problems. Realistic tasks have the advantage of being more attractive than other divergent thinking tasks (such as the Alternative Uses Task; Guilford, 1968), because the realism can be more interesting than an abstract problem, and it is possible that the individual has more relevant experience and, therefore, relevant information (Runco, Dow, & Smith, 2006). The realistic problems are open-ended questions, but unlike other divergent tasks, the problems focus on situations that participants might actually experience. Specifically, in the present study two general problems that have been used in past research (e.g., Runco, Illies, & Eisenman, 2005) are adopted, along with two problems specifically referring to the COVID-19 scenario. An example problem for the COVID-19 scenario is: “At the end of the Coronavirus emergency, open-air concerts are restarting. Finally, you can listen live you preferred artist, but there is the obligation to ensure a distance of 1 meter, otherwise a fine of 300 euros/dollars is imposed. You are still determined to go to the concert. What do you do to be sure that no one will approach you less than 1 meter?” 
Participants are asked to produce as many alternative solutions as they can in 3 minutes for each problem. Each response will be then evaluated for originality by two independent expert raters. All the responses will be copied into a spreadsheet and sorted alphabetically within each problem. This method will ensure that the raters will be blind to several factors that could bias their ratings: the response serial position in the set, the total number of responses in the set, and the preceding and following responses. The two raters will read all the responses prior to scoring them, and they will score the responses separately. Each response will receive a rating on a 1 (not at all original) to 5 (highly original) scale using the procedure proposed by Silvia and colleagues (2008). Furthermore, the fluency score as the total number of responses in the production of alternative solutions for each participant will be calculated both for general problems and for COVID-19 problems.


- Creative self-beliefs.
Self-perception of creativity is evaluated with the Short Scale of the Creative Self (SSCS; Karwowski et al., 2012). This scale provides separate indicators of creative self-efficacy (CSE) and creative personal identity (CPI). These two constructs are evaluated by 11 items, 6 which measures CSE and 5 which measures CPI. Exemplary items are: “I trust my creative abilities” and “Being a creative person is important to me”. All items are rated using a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 “definitely not” to 5 “definitely yes”.


- Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) Scale.
The TIPI Scale is a methodology developed within the Big-Five theoretical framework, which has been demonstrated to allow a rapid and valid assessment of the five personality dimensions (Gosling, Rentfrow, & Swann, 2003). Each item in this 10-item version represents one pole of the Big Five dimensions. As for format, each item consists of two descriptors, separated by a comma. Each item is rated on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (disagree strongly) to 7 (agree strongly). Participants are instructed to write one of the seven numbers next to each of the 10 items to indicate the extent to which they see themselves fitting the descriptors.


- Mental health outcomes: depression and distress.
Depression is assessed with the 9-item Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9; Spitzer et al. 1999), which is a self-report questionnaire that efficiently allow a rapid DSM-IV criteria-based depression diagnosis. PHQ-9 has been demonstrated to have a high criterion validity as a diagnostic measure, both with respect to DSM-IV and ICD-10 criteria (Loewe, Spitzer, et al., 2004; Loewe, Grafe, et al., 2004). Moreover, it has been shown that PHQ-9 is particularly sensitive to change and accurately reflect depression outcomes (Loewe, Kroenke, et al., 2004). Specifically, the scale make reference to symptoms happening in the last 14 days.
Distress to the COVID-19 situation is assessed with the 22-item Impact of Event Scale-Revised scale (IES-R; Creamer et al., 2003; Weiss & Marmar, 1997) which is probably the most diffused measure in the field of traumatic stress. This scale assessed the three dimensions defining a traumatic stress reaction through three subscales: intrusion, avoidance, and hyperarousal. Specifically, the scale asks respondents about the frequency with which each symptom has occurred over the past week. In particular, for the present study the scale makes specifically reference to the COVID-19 emergence, giving a description of the COVID-19 outbreak to which participants should refer during the completion of the scale ("Local, state, and national governments have taken measures aimed at preventing the rapid spread of the COVID-19 virus, including social isolation. These measures have been taken because of the dangerous nature of the virus and the present lack of a vaccine or an effective treatment for the illness the virus causes").


- Demographic variables (which will be used to provide a specific characterisation of the sample tested in the study):

Age (from 18 to 100) 

Gender (3 options):
1.	 Male
2.	 Female
3.	 Other

Have you been hospitalized for a neurological or mental health condition (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No

In which country are you nowadays (open question)?

In which region are you nowadays (open question)?
[This question and the previous one have been merged in the US version of the survey into a single question "In which country are you nowadays?" including the list of the 50 states to choose from] 

Maximum educational degree achieved (6 options): 
1.	 Primary school
2.	 Lower secondary school
3.	 High secondary school

Exposure to COVID-19 will be scored as a sum (ranging from 3 to 12) of the following variables: number of infected persons in participant’s region at the moment of the participation in the study (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high taking into account the national average); number of contacts outside of with whom participant was currently quarantining in the last 14 days (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high); frequency of contacts with persons affected from Coronavirus in the last 14 days (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high); acquaintances affected by Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes); relatives affected by Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes); death among persons the participant know due to Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes).

The pattern of relations specified via the model of hypotheses proposed in the attached Figure will be investigated through a structural equation model using the Mplus software (Muthén & Muthén, 1998–2015), with an observed score for the COVID-19 exposure variable and four latent variables (Plasticity, defined by the Openness and Extraversion manifest variables; Stability, defined by the Conscientiousness, Neuroticism, and Agreeableness manifest variables; Creative Self-Beliefs, defined by the Creative Identity and  Creative Self-Efficacy manifest variables; Psychological Discomfort defined by IES-R Avoidance, Intrusion, and Hyperarousal, and the PHQ-9 Depression manifest variables; Creative performance defined by the manifest variables of Fluency and Originality in the two types of divergent thinking problems).

q19.value: The main predictors and the hypothesized mediation effect will be examined using a bootstrap estimation with 5,000 samples (Muthén & Muthén, 1998–2015). The model fit will be estimated with the following indices: the chi-square statistic and the related p, the Tucker-Lewis index (TLI), the comparative fit index (CFI), the root mean squared error of approximation (RMSEA), and the standardized root mean squared residual (SRMR). According to Marsh et al. (2004) as well as Hu and Bentler (1999), a good model fit will be indicated by a TLI and a CFI above 0.95, an RMSEA below 0.06, an SRMR under 0.08 and a small ratio (< 3) between the chi-square and the degrees of freedom (χ2/df ).

q20.value: Participants completing less than 80% of the online study will be excluded from the data analysis.

q22.value: A multi-group analysis will be performed to test the structural invariance of the model between the four countries involved in the study (Italy, France, Poland, United States). Moreover, a direct  effect of the Exposure to COVID-19 on creative performance and creative self-beliefs will be tested as well as an indirect effect (via creative self-beliefs and creative performance) of the Exposure to COVID-19 on Psychological discomfort will be analyzed. Finally, in the case of a poor fit of the model, modification indices will be adopted to understand where the model is particularly poor.

registration_responses.q2:
In the present study we are testing a specific model of hypotheses (see Figure in Analysis Plan), which will be analysed through a structural equation model approach.
- In particular, as demonstrated by recent research, we can expect that the increase of the exposure to COVID-19 might enhance the degree of psychological discomfort (Gao et al., 2020; Lai et al., 2020).
- Along with the exposure to COVID-19, we expect that personality, particularly the stability huge trait (defined by neuroticism, agreeableness, and conscientiousness) will be negatively associated with the degree of mental suffering (Kotov et al., 2010).
- At the same time, according to past research, we can expect that the plasticity huge trait (defined by openness and extraversion) can predict creative self-beliefs (Karwowski & Leduda, 2016).
- Finally, we hypothesize that creative self-beliefs will be negatively associated with the degree of mental suffering both directly and indirectly via a mediation effect on creative performance.
- The ability of seeing alternative answers in the search of an original and effective solution to open problems (measured through the divergent thinking task, Realistic Problems) could therefore be predicted by creative self-beliefs and impact on the mental health outcomes by reducing the mental suffering associated to the COVID-19 outcome.

registration_responses.q6.question:
In the present study, involving participants over different European countries (Italy, France, and Poland) and the United States, mental health outcomes are measured in terms of distress and depression symptoms emerging as a consequence of the exposure to coronavirus events (such as the number of infections and deaths in the residence region, number of acquaintances suffering from COVID-19, number of family members suffering from COVID-19, number of contacts with people affected from COVID-19, etc, - See Variables Section). Creative performance is measured here in terms of originality and fluency in a classical divergent thinking (DT) task, the Realistic Problem task (Runco, Illies, & Eisenman, 2005), which measured DT abilities in a series of realistic situations from the natural environment. Specifically, for the present study two problems related to the everyday life are used and two problems specifically referring to the COVID-19 situation. The context manipulation (everyday vs. COVID-19) of the problems allows us to explore the creative performance as a function of the specific stressful condition associated to the COVID-19. Creative self-beliefs are measured through the Short Scale of Creative Scale (Karwowski et al., 2012), measuring creative self-efficacy and creative identity. Finally, we take into account the predictive effect of personality, which can predict both creativity (Karwowski & Lebuda, 2016; Feist, 1998) and mental health outcomes (Kotov et al., 2010). 

The study will be conducting as an observational study via a survey created through the online PsyToolkit platform (Stoet, 2010, 2017). Using institutional channels (University websites) and social networks, the online link to the study will be spread in order to recruit volunteers. The online procedure has a total duration of around 20 minutes. After the initial written informed consent, participants will complete four blocks of tasks composed by: 1) two realistic problems (one general and one COVID-related problem), 2) two questionnaires (SSCS scale and PHQ-9 scale), 3) two realistic problems (one general and one COVID-related problem), 4) two questionnaires (TIPI, IES-R). Within each block the order of the tasks/questionnaires will be fully randomized across participants. Finally, a series of demographic questions (gender, age, nation, region, education level, type of work) along with questions asking for exposure to COVID-19 (see variables section) are included.
registration_responses.q10.question:
The study will be conducting using the online PsyToolkit platform (Stoet, 2010, 2017). Using institutional channels (University websites) and social networks, the online link to the study will be spread in order to recruit volunteers (recruiting participants from the age of 18 years).

Around 600 participants are planned to be involved in the study. Participants completing less than 80% of the online study will be excluded from the data analysis. Moreover, participants reporting current or past neurological or psychopathological problems will be excluded from the study.

We have set up the study in PsyToolKit and because of the exceptionality of the situation related to the COVID-19 emergence we intend to begin the study promptly. We anticipate that data collection will take approximately two weeks since several authors will collect data simultaneously over different countries in Europe and the United States. The scoring of the data would take around three weeks as well as data analysis would take approximately three weeks/one month.
registration_responses.q15.question:
- Exposure to COVID-19.
Exposure to COVID-19 will be scored as a sum (ranging from 3 to 12) of the following variables: number of infected persons in participant’s state/region at the moment of the participation in the study (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high taking into account the national average); number of contacts outside of with whom participant was currently quarantining in the last 14 days (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high); frequency of contacts with persons affected from Coronavirus in the last 14 days (1=low; 2=medium; 3=high); acquaintances affected by Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes); relatives affected by Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes); death among persons the participant know due to Coronavirus (0=no; 1=yes).

In the following the items and scales for this variable:

How much contact in person have you had outside of with whom you are currently quarantining in the last 14 days (4 options)?
1. None
2. On one or two occasions
3. About once a week
4. About once a day

How frequently have you come into contact in person with someone with a Coronavirus diagnosis in the last 14 days (5 options)?
1.	Never
2.	Rarely
3.	About once a week
4.	Several times a week
5.	Every day

Had been Coronavirus diagnosed in people you know (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No

Had been Coronavirus diagnosed in a family member (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No

Have you lost anyone you know to Coronavirus (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No


- Divergent thinking performance: Realistic Problems.
Creative performance is scored through a classical divergent thinking task: realistic problems. Realistic tasks have the advantage of being more attractive than other divergent thinking tasks (such as the Alternative Uses Task; Guilford, 1968), because the realism can be more interesting than an abstract problem, and it is possible that the individual has more relevant experience and, therefore, relevant information (Runco, Dow, & Smith, 2006). The realistic problems are open-ended questions, but unlike other divergent tasks, the problems focus on situations that participants might actually experience. Specifically, in the present study two general problems that have been used in past research (e.g., Runco, Illies, & Eisenman, 2005) are adopted, along with two problems specifically referring to the COVID-19 scenario. An example problem for the COVID-19 scenario is: “At the end of the Coronavirus emergency, open-air concerts are restarting. Finally, you can listen live you preferred artist, but there is the obligation to ensure a distance of 1 meter, otherwise a fine of 300 euros/dollars is imposed. You are still determined to go to the concert. What do you do to be sure that no one will approach you less than 1 meter?” 
Participants are asked to produce as many alternative solutions as they can in 3 minutes for each problem. Each response will be then evaluated for originality by two independent expert raters. All the responses will be copied into a spreadsheet and sorted alphabetically within each problem. This method will ensure that the raters will be blind to several factors that could bias their ratings: the response serial position in the set, the total number of responses in the set, and the preceding and following responses. The two raters will read all the responses prior to scoring them, and they will score the responses separately. Each response will receive a rating on a 1 (not at all original) to 5 (highly original) scale using the procedure proposed by Silvia and colleagues (2008). Furthermore, the fluency score as the total number of responses in the production of alternative solutions for each participant will be calculated both for general problems and for COVID-19 problems.


- Creative self-beliefs.
Self-perception of creativity is evaluated with the Short Scale of the Creative Self (SSCS; Karwowski et al., 2012). This scale provides separate indicators of creative self-efficacy (CSE) and creative personal identity (CPI). These two constructs are evaluated by 11 items, 6 which measures CSE and 5 which measures CPI. Exemplary items are: “I trust my creative abilities” and “Being a creative person is important to me”. All items are rated using a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 “definitely not” to 5 “definitely yes”.


- Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) Scale.
The TIPI Scale is a methodology developed within the Big-Five theoretical framework, which has been demonstrated to allow a rapid and valid assessment of the five personality dimensions (Gosling, Rentfrow, & Swann, 2003). Each item in this 10-item version represents one pole of the Big Five dimensions. As for format, each item consists of two descriptors, separated by a comma. Each item is rated on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (disagree strongly) to 7 (agree strongly). Participants are instructed to write one of the seven numbers next to each of the 10 items to indicate the extent to which they see themselves fitting the descriptors.


- Mental health outcomes: depression and distress.
Depression is assessed with the 9-item Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9; Spitzer et al. 1999), which is a self-report questionnaire that efficiently allow a rapid DSM-IV criteria-based depression diagnosis. PHQ-9 has been demonstrated to have a high criterion validity as a diagnostic measure, both with respect to DSM-IV and ICD-10 criteria (Loewe, Spitzer, et al., 2004; Loewe, Grafe, et al., 2004). Moreover, it has been shown that PHQ-9 is particularly sensitive to change and accurately reflect depression outcomes (Loewe, Kroenke, et al., 2004). Specifically, the scale make reference to symptoms happening in the last 14 days.
Distress to the COVID-19 situation is assessed with the 22-item Impact of Event Scale-Revised scale (IES-R; Creamer et al., 2003; Weiss & Marmar, 1997) which is probably the most diffused measure in the field of traumatic stress. This scale assessed the three dimensions defining a traumatic stress reaction through three subscales: intrusion, avoidance, and hyperarousal. Specifically, the scale asks respondents about the frequency with which each symptom has occurred over the past week. In particular, for the present study the scale makes specifically reference to the COVID-19 emergence, giving a description of the COVID-19 outbreak to which participants should refer during the completion of the scale ("Local, state, and national governments have taken measures aimed at preventing the rapid spread of the COVID-19 virus, including social isolation. These measures have been taken because of the dangerous nature of the virus and the present lack of a vaccine or an effective treatment for the illness the virus causes").


- Demographic variables (which will be used to provide a specific characterisation of the sample tested in the study):

Age (from 18 to 100) 

Gender (3 options):
1.	 Male
2.	 Female
3.	 Other

Have you been hospitalized for a neurological or mental health condition (2 options)?
1.	 Yes
2.	 No

In which country are you nowadays (open question)?

In which region are you nowadays (open question)?
[This question and the previous one have been merged in the US version of the survey into a single question "In which country are you nowadays?" including the list of the 50 states to choose from] 

Maximum educational degree achieved (6 options): 
1.	 Primary school
2.	 Lower secondary school
3.	 High secondary school
4.	 Master-Degree
5.	 Post-graduate degree
6.	 Ph.D.
[Because of a different organisation in the educational system, this question presents the following options in the US version of the survey:
- High School

- Graduate Degree]

1.	 Unemployed

6.	Self-employed
7.	 Pensioner/retiree

attributes.title: RIPOD
attributes.description: The clinical study was conducted at the University Hospital Aachen and was designed by Prof. Natalia Chechko and Prof. Simon Eickhoff. Prof. Natalia Chechko is responsible for the clinical execution of the study.

q3.value: Postpartum depression (PPD) affects up to 15 % of mothers after childbirth. In addition to the emotional burden for the mother, it can severely affect the cognitive, emotional and social development of the offspring. Although there are effective options for early intervention, a major problem in the treatment of PPD is its early recognition. In the past, attempts have been made to predict postpartum depression. However, most attempts have either been late in the postpartum period, only reached a low sensitivity, or were only based on a single time point for prediction. Furthermore, adjustment disorder (AD), another condition that is frequently associated with childbirth, has been ignored as potential differential diagnosis in those predictions. Therefore, we aimed at predicting the diagnosis of PPD as early as possible in our explanatory analysis. We evaluated the potential predictive power of combinations of demographic and clinical risk factors, postnatal depression and attachment scores, and mood and stress levels. Our classifiers reached a high balanced accuracy (BA) already at week 3 for the differentiation of healthy controls from PPD and AD (HC vs. PPD: BA = 0.87, HC vs. AD: BA = 0.91), and a high balanced accuracy for the differentiation of PPD and AD at week 6 (BA = 0.76). The best classifiers included either the mood level alone (PPD vs. AD), mood level in combination with postnatal depression scores (HC vs. PPD), or mood level in combination with postnatal depression and attachment scores (HC vs. AD). Although the results are promising, a replication in an independent sample is necessary. Therefore, we aim to replicate the findings from our exploration cohort in an independent validation cohort.

The combination of baseline postnatal depression scores, postnatal depression scores at week 3, and mood scores at week 3 using logistic regression will allow for accurate discrimination of postpartum depression and healthy controls at week 3.

The combination of baseline postnatal depression scores, postnatal depression and attachment scores at week 3, and mood scores at week 3 using logistic regression will allow for accurate discrimination of adjustment disorder and healthy controls at week 3.

Mood at week 6 using logistic regression will allow for accurate discrimination of postpartum depression and adjustment disorder at week 6.

question.value: The current study has a mixed design with 1 between-subjects factor (group) including 3 levels (healthy controls, postpartum depression, and adjustment disorder) and 1 within-subjects factor (week) including 13 levels (week 0 - week 12). At T0 (two to five days postpartum), a clinical interview is conducted to check for current conditions. Additionally, the participants fill in a stressful life events and an anamnestic questionnaire. The anamnestic questionnaire asks for demographic (e.g. age) and clinical (e.g. psychiatric history) information. At T4 (12 weeks postpartum), a final diagnosis is made based on DSM-5 criteria. Furthermore, participants fill in a second anamnestic questionnaire asking for the breastfeeding status and the support at home. In addition to continuous (bi-daily) measurement of mood and stress levels, postnatal depression and attachment questionnaires are filled in by the participants at baseline (T0, only postnatal depression questionnaire), three weeks postpartum (T1), six weeks postpartum (T2), nine weeks postpartum (T3), and 12 weeks postpartum (T4).

question.value: The same data collection procedure was used for the exploration and validation cohort. New mothers were recruited following childbirth at the University Hospital Aachen. More specifically, the recruitment was conducted at the Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics within the first two to five days postpartum. Written informed consent was obtained from all participants, and the study was approved by the ethics committee of the Medical Faculty of RWTH University Hospital Aachen. Exclusion criteria were based either on the maternal psychiatric status or on the child’s condition and expected outcome. Exclusion criteria based on the maternal psychiatric status: 1) alcoholic or psychotic substance dependency or use during current pregnancy, 2) antidepressant or antipsychotic medication during pregnancy, 3) history of psychosis or manic episodes, 4) current depressive episode at the beginning of or during pregnancy, and 5) lack of sufficient understanding of German or English. Exclusion criteria based on the child’s condition and expected outcome: 1) genetic defects (e.g. trisomy), very premature birth (i.e. less than 26 weeks of gestation) and very low weight (<1000g), pathological neurological assessment based on the German Child Health tests (U2) within the first three to ten days of life.

q13.value: The exploration cohort included 308 mothers. The validation sample includes 195 mothers.

q14.value: For the validation cohort, there was a time constraint. The validation sample was collected since November 2018 until December 2019.

question.value:
The single outcome variable was group, which was defined in a clinical interview based on DSM-5 criteria. The mothers in both cohorts were either healthy, or suffered postpartum depression or adjustment disorder.
The following demographic and clinical information were obtained at T0 (two to five days postpartum):
Age (in years), family status (no partner/partner), marital status (unmarried/married), total amount of children, education (in years), completed professional education (no/yes), annual income (≤10,000€/≤20,000€/ ≤50,000€/>50,000€), personal psychiatric history (no/yes), familial psychiatric history (no/yes), psychiatric diagnosis in previous pregnancy (no/yes), birth complications (no/yes), week of gestation (in days), birth-related psychological and physical traumas (no/yes), child’s gender (male/female/both(twins)), child’s birth weight (in gram), child relocated to another ward (no/yes), breastfeeding T0 (no/yes), premenstrual syndrome (PMS; no PMS/mild PMS/PMS), postpartum blues (no/yes), stressful life events (no/yes).
The following clinical information was obtained at T4 (12 weeks postpartum):
Quality of support at home (insufficient/sufficient), breastfeeding T4 (no/yes), and Hamilton depression score (no/mild/moderate/severe depression; only for postpartum depression).
The postnatal depression score was measured using the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) at baseline, after three, six, nine, and 12 weeks. The maternal attachment was measured using the Maternal Postnatal Attachment Scale (MPAS) after three, six, nine, and 12 weeks. Furthermore, mood and stress levels were measured continuously (bi-daily) on a scale from 1 to 10 (1 = low mood/low stress, 10 = high mood/high stress).

For the exploratory analysis, we calculated the mood-stress difference by transforming mood and stress levels into Z-scores and subtracting them (i.e. Z-score mood MINUS Z-score stress). Furthermore, we calculated the weekly mean of mood, stress, and mood-stress difference. Additionally, we calculated change scores to baseline (i.e. mood/stress/mood-stress difference score of current week MINUS score of baseline week/week 0) and to the preceding week (i.e. score of current week MINUS score of preceding week). We will repeat these calculations for the validation cohort.

To evaluate the predictive power of combinations of demographic and clinical risk factors, mood, and stress levels, we used a logistic regression classifier (MATLAB built-in mnrfit and mnrval functions) performing 1000 repetitions of three-fold cross-validation by randomly drawing two thirds for training and one third for testing. The analysis was performed for each group comparison separately. An independent samples t-test was performed in the training data prior to the machine learning (ML) analysis to determine the baseline variables to be included. Only significant predictors (p<.05) were included in the logistic models. Nine feature combinations were evaluated: baseline anamnestic data only (1), mood scores (2), stress scores (3), mood-stress difference scores (4), mood scores incl. change scores (change to baseline and to preceding week) (5), stress scores incl. change scores (6), mood-stress difference scores (7), combination of mood and stress scores incl. change scores (8) and combination of mood, stress and mood-stress difference scores incl. change scores (9). These features were either used alone (1), with only baseline anamnestic data and baseline EPDS scores (2), EPDS (3), or MPAS scores (4), with a combination of baseline anamnestic data and EPDS (5) or MPAS scores (6), with a combination of EPDS and MPAS scores (7), or with a combination of baseline risk factors, EPDS and MPAS scores (8).  For evaluation, the balanced accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive values were calculated. More specifically, the balanced accuracy was calculated by summing sensitivity and specificity, and averaging their sum. Additionally, we calculated ROC curves and their associated AUCs (out-of-sample). Finally, we calculated logistic regression coefficients for the best model in the whole sample per group comparison.
For replication, we will use the coefficients from our exploration analysis in the class probability formula (p = 1/(1 + exp(-betaX))) for logistic regression to obtain the ‘predicted’ group based on the classifier. Then, we will compute the balanced accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, area under the curve, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value by comparing the predicted and actual group.
The betaX for each group comparison:
betaX  (HC vs. PPD) = 2.0138 - 0.1233 * baseline EPDS - 0.5598 * EPDS at week 3 + 0.7112 * mood at week 3
betaX (HC vs. AD) = - 13.3104 - 0.2959 * baseline EPDS - 1.1623 * EPDS at week 3 + 0.2679 * MPAS at week 3 + 0.7164 * mood at week 3
betaX (PPD vs. AD) = - 4.1463 + 0.6578 * mood at week 6

q20.value: For the comparison of healthy controls and postpartum depression, healthy controls will be coded as 1 and postpartum depression as 2. Similarly, for the comparison of healthy controls and adjustment disorder, healthy controls will be coded as 1 and adjustment disorder as 2. For the comparison of adjustment disorder and postpartum depression, adjustment disorder will be coded as 1 and postpartum depression as 2.

q21.value: To test our hypotheses, we will compare the obtained values (i.e. balanced accuracy, etc.) with chance-level-performance. If our classifier's accuracy is higher than the highest accuracy  in the 95 % confidence interval of the chance-level-classifier, we consider our classfier accurate. We will randomly permute the 'predicted' labels 1000 times and calculate the balanced accuracy. Finally, we will compute the 95 % confidence interval of this accuracy.

q22.value: We will verify that each subject participated in all measurements.

q23.value: Subjects not completing all measurements will be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value: We will perform an exploratory analysis regarding the comparability of the groups in both cohorts. We will examine, whether the groups in both cohorts are comparable regarding demographic and clinical factors incl. mood, stress, EPDS, and MPAS.

registration_responses.q3: Postpartum depression (PPD) affects up to 15 % of mothers after childbirth. In addition to the emotional burden for the mother, it can severely affect the cognitive, emotional and social development of the offspring. Although there are effective options for early intervention, a major problem in the treatment of PPD is its early recognition. In the past, attempts have been made to predict postpartum depression. However, most attempts have either been late in the postpartum period, only reached a low sensitivity, or were only based on a single time point for prediction. Furthermore, adjustment disorder (AD), another condition that is frequently associated with childbirth, has been ignored as potential differential diagnosis in those predictions. Therefore, we aimed at predicting the diagnosis of PPD as early as possible in our explanatory analysis. We evaluated the potential predictive power of combinations of demographic and clinical risk factors, postnatal depression and attachment scores, and mood and stress levels. Our classifiers reached a high balanced accuracy (BA) already at week 3 for the differentiation of healthy controls from PPD and AD (HC vs. PPD: BA = 0.87, HC vs. AD: BA = 0.91), and a high balanced accuracy for the differentiation of PPD and AD at week 6 (BA = 0.76). The best classifiers included either the mood level alone (PPD vs. AD), mood level in combination with postnatal depression scores (HC vs. PPD), or mood level in combination with postnatal depression and attachment scores (HC vs. AD). Although the results are promising, a replication in an independent sample is necessary. Therefore, we aim to replicate the findings from our exploration cohort in an independent validation cohort.

Mood at week 6 using logistic regression will allow for accurate discrimination of postpartum depression and adjustment disorder at week 6.

attributes.title: Prompted Rationality
attributes.description: How can physical distancing in public places be facilitated? In five hypothetical scenarios describing common situations that may challenge adherence to governmental guidelines to keep distance to others, we examine the effects of an empathy prompt to consider the health and wellbeing of close others as compared to a condition emphasizing the benefits of distance for unidentified others, a condition explaining the relevance of distancing for one’s own health, and a control condition. Additionally, we will investigate the motivation to adhere to physical distance guidelines by examining how much effort participants are willing to exert in ten hypothetical situations, both immediately and in the future.

q1.value: Denise De Ridder, Chris Harris, Herbert Hoijtink, caroline hummels, erik hans klijn, Lars Tummers, Jonas Wachner, Marielle Zondervan-Zwijnenburg, Henk Aarts

q2.value:
How can physical distancing in public places be facilitated? In five hypothetical scenarios describing common situations that may challenge adherence to governmental guidelines to keep distance to others, we examine the effects of an empathy prompt to consider the health and wellbeing of close others as compared to a condition emphasizing the benefits of distance for unidentified others, a condition explaining the relevance of distancing for one’s own health, and a control condition. Additionally, we will investigate the motivation to adhere to physical distance guidelines by examining how much effort participants are willing to exert in ten hypothetical situations, both immediately and in the future.

Confirmatory Part of the Project
 
There are four conditions: control, own-health, empathy close, and empathy unidentified others. Effectiveness is measured by three variables: motivation to adhere to physical distancing immediately, motivation to adhere to physical distancing in the (near) future (in ten hypothetical situations), and adherence to physical distancing (in five hypothetical situations). There are two competing expectations: 
 
I.	The effectiveness in the control condition is smaller than in the self condition, which in turn is smaller than in the empathy unidentified, which in turn is smaller than in the empathy close condition.
II.	The effectiveness in the control condition is smaller than in the self condition, which in turn is smaller than in the empathy close, which in turn is smaller than in the empathy unidentified condition.
 
 
Exploratory Part of the Project
 
Reliability and factor analysis will be used to evaluate the consistency of the items used to measure motivation immediately, motivation in the (near) future, and adherence, and the relations between these three measures.
 
Additional variables will be included in the survey: demographics, opinions on governmental guidelines with respect to physical distancing, physical distancing behavior in general, and familiarity with situations challenging physical distancing (see the questionnaire for a full overview). These variables will be used to describe sample of persons that participate in the study. Furthermore these variables will be used to explore whether they moderate the relation between the prompts and the three measures of effectiveness.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Data will be collected via an online survey using Lucid (https://luc.id/). A complete overview of the questions asked and the manner in which the questions are scored can be found in the questionnaire that is uploaded with this pre-registration.

q7.value: Each person that participates is randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. Also the set of 10 items measuring immediate and future motivation will be presented to each participant in a random order, and, the set of 5 items measuring adherence to governmental guidelines will be presented to each participant in a random order

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
An online survey will be used to collect data in both the Netherlands and the United Kingdom. 
1)	See https://luc.id/quality/ for the suppliers that provide Lucid with participants.
2)	The minimum age for participations is 16 years.
3)	Whether or not participants are payed and how differs between “the suppliers” of Lucid. See https://luc.id/quality/ for an overview of the suppliers.
4)	The survey will be opened on April 30th 2020 and continue until the require numbers of participants (for UK and the Netherlands 300 in each of the four conditions) has been obtained.
 
Only persons that give both “immediate” and “future” answers to at least 9 of the 10 motivation items AND that give answers to both questions asked for at least 4 of the 5 adherence items will be included in the analyses.

q11.value: For the Netherlands 1200 persons (300 in each of the four groups). For the United Kingdom 1200 persons (300 in each of the four groups).

q12.value: According to Jacob Cohen (1992), A power primer, Psychological Bulletin, 112, 155-159. For a one-way ANOVA with four groups, a small effect size can be detected with 80% power is the sample size per group is 388 for alpha = .01 and 274 for alpha=.05. Our sample size of 300 is between 388 and 274. Since better means are not available (we will use Bayesian evaluation of informative hypotheses) we used Cohen’s power analysis to get an indication of the required sample sizes.

question.value: There are four conditions to which participants are randomly assigned: control, self, close others and unidentified others.
All the items (and their response format) can be found in the questionnaire that is uploaded with this pre-registration.

Motivation to adhere to physical distancing immediately is measured by the sum of the 10 1-9 scores.

Motivation to adhere to physical distancing in the (near) future  is measured by the sum of the 10 1-9 scores.

Adherence to governmental guidelines is measured by the number of positive responses among the 5 A/B scores: Que for bus – B, Best friend – A; Supermarket – B; Market – A; Park – B.

Previous exposure to the five situations “Adherence to governmental guidelines” is measured by the number of “Yes” responses.

Confirmatory Part of the Project
 
For each country and each of the three measures (that is, six times in total) the data will be modelled using a one-way analysis of variance. We will evaluate the following set of informative hypotheses using the Bayes factor and posterior model probabilities as is implemented in the R package bain (M denotes the mean score of the measure at hand in the country at hand):
 
H0: Mcontrol = Mself = Mempathyunidentified = Mempathyclose
H1: Mcontrol < Mself < Mempathyunidentified < Mempathyclose
H2: Mcontrol < Mself < Mempathyclose < Mempathyunidentified
Hc: not H0 & not H1 & not H2
 
Once the best of these four hypotheses is selected, a further description will be provides by presenting Cohen’s d for the adjacent groups in the hypotheses.
 
Exploratory Part of the Project
 
Reliability analyses will be executed to determine the consistency of the items making up each of the three measures.
Factor analysis will be executed to determine to which degree the three measures are overlapping/distinct.
For each of the additional variables included in the survey it will be investigated if they moderate the relation between condition and the three outcome measures.

q19.value:
Confirmatory Part of the Project
 
Bayes factor, posterior model probabilities, and Cohen’s d. No cut-off criteria will be used.
 
Exploratory Part of the Project
 
Reliability analysis: item-total correlations and alpha will be presented and interpreted.
Factor analysis: scree plot and standardized factor loadings, will be presented and interpreted.
Moderation analysis: If an additional variable is categorical, for each category the same analysis as described in the Analysis Plan for the Confirmatory Part of the Project. Idem if an additional variable is continuous, but then after splitting it into a low and high category using median splitting.

q20.value:
Only persons that give both “immediate” and “future” answers to at least 9 of the 10 motivation items AND that give answers to both questions asked for at least 4 of the 5 adherence items will be included in the analyses. Person mean imputation will be used to deal with the missing values. 

We will not remove persons using the “outlier” argument.

q21.value:
Confirmatory Part of the Project
 
Only persons that give both “immediate” and “future” answers to at least 9 of the 10 motivation items AND that give answers to both questions asked for at least 4 of the 5 adherence items will be included in the analyses. Person mean imputation will be used to deal with the missing values.
 
Exploratory Part of the Project
 
Missing data occurring in other than the “immediate motivation”, “future motivation”, and “adherence” questions, will be dealt with using single imputation using the R package MICE.

q22.value: This has been addressed in our responses to the previous questions.

Factor analysis: scree plot and standardized factor loadings, will be presented and interpreted.
Moderation analysis: If an additional variable is categorical, for each category the same analysis as described in the Analysis Plan for the Confirmatory Part of the Project. Idem if an additional variable is continuous, but then after splitting it into a low and high category using median splitting.
registration_responses.q20:
Only persons that give both “immediate” and “future” answers to at least 9 of the 10 motivation items AND that give answers to both questions asked for at least 4 of the 5 adherence items will be included in the analyses. Person mean imputation will be used to deal with the missing values. 

We will not remove persons using the “outlier” argument.
registration_responses.q21:
Confirmatory Part of the Project
 
Only persons that give both “immediate” and “future” answers to at least 9 of the 10 motivation items AND that give answers to both questions asked for at least 4 of the 5 adherence items will be included in the analyses. Person mean imputation will be used to deal with the missing values.
 
Exploratory Part of the Project
 
Missing data occurring in other than the “immediate motivation”, “future motivation”, and “adherence” questions, will be dealt with using single imputation using the R package MICE.

registration_responses.q10.question:
An online survey will be used to collect data in both the Netherlands and the United Kingdom. 
1)	See https://luc.id/quality/ for the suppliers that provide Lucid with participants.
2)	The minimum age for participations is 16 years.
3)	Whether or not participants are payed and how differs between “the suppliers” of Lucid. See https://luc.id/quality/ for an overview of the suppliers.
4)	The survey will be opened on April 30th 2020 and continue until the require numbers of participants (for UK and the Netherlands 300 in each of the four conditions) has been obtained.

registration_responses.q14.question: There are four conditions to which participants are randomly assigned: control, self, close others and unidentified others.
registration_responses.q15.question: All the items (and their response format) can be found in the questionnaire that is uploaded with this pre-registration.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Motivation to adhere to physical distancing immediately is measured by the sum of the 10 1-9 scores.

Motivation to adhere to physical distancing in the (near) future  is measured by the sum of the 10 1-9 scores.

Adherence to governmental guidelines is measured by the number of positive responses among the 5 A/B scores: Que for bus – B, Best friend – A; Supermarket – B; Market – A; Park – B.

Previous exposure to the five situations “Adherence to governmental guidelines” is measured by the number of “Yes” responses.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Confirmatory Part of the Project
 
For each country and each of the three measures (that is, six times in total) the data will be modelled using a one-way analysis of variance. We will evaluate the following set of informative hypotheses using the Bayes factor and posterior model probabilities as is implemented in the R package bain (M denotes the mean score of the measure at hand in the country at hand):
 
H0: Mcontrol = Mself = Mempathyunidentified = Mempathyclose
H1: Mcontrol < Mself < Mempathyunidentified < Mempathyclose
H2: Mcontrol < Mself < Mempathyclose < Mempathyunidentified
Hc: not H0 & not H1 & not H2
 
Once the best of these four hypotheses is selected, a further description will be provides by presenting Cohen’s d for the adjacent groups in the hypotheses.
 
Exploratory Part of the Project
 
Reliability analyses will be executed to determine the consistency of the items making up each of the three measures.
Factor analysis will be executed to determine to which degree the three measures are overlapping/distinct.
For each of the additional variables included in the survey it will be investigated if they moderate the relation between condition and the three outcome measures.

attributes.title: COVID-19: Effects of a Global Stressor on Couples
attributes.description: COVID-19 is the newest type of coronavirus, which gained global attention when an outbreak occurred in Wuhan, China December 2019. Since December, at least 125 countries have a recorded case of COVID-19. As such, global prevention measures have been taken, including quarantines and travel bans (World Health Organization, 2020). This study aims to understand the effects of a global stressor (COVID-19) on individual and relational well-being for individuals in a romantic relationship.

q1.value: Ashley Randall, Casey Totenhagen, Claudia Chiarolanza, Emanuele Basili, RIchmond Aryeetey, Eran Bar-Kalifa, Michael Boiger, Susan Dianne Boon, Audrey Brassard, Silvia Donato, Katherine Carnelley, Reza Fallahchai, Mimi Fitriana, Stanley O. Gaines, Jr., Barani Kanth, Evangelos Karademas, Gery Karantzas, Tamas Martos, Jean Carlos Natividade, Petruta Rusu, Selina Andrea Landolt, Marie-France Lafontaine, Anne Milek, Katherine Péloquin, Ana Paula Relvas, Pingkan Cynthia Belinda Rumondor, Sultan Shujja, Burcu Ucok, Lesley Verhofstadt, Gyesook Yoo, Feng Xu

q2.value:
COVID-19 is the newest type of coronavirus, which gained global attention when an outbreak occurred in Wuhan, China December 2019. Since December 2019, at least 125 countries have a recorded case of COVID-19. As such, global prevention measures have been taken, including quarantines and travel bans (World Health Organization, 2020). 

This study aims to understand the effects of a global stressor (COVID-19) on individual and relational well-being for individuals in a romantic relationship living across the world. We hypothesize to see an increase self-reported symptoms of depression, anxiety, and stress from pre- and post-COVID-19 travel bans (H1). Symptoms of psychological distress associated with COVID-19 bans (post-COVID-19 controlling for pre-COVID-19) will be negatively associated with relationship quality, as measured by the PRQC (H2). Furthermore, it is hypothesized that positive DC will mitigate these effects, as measured by the DCI (H3). Between country differences for these hypotheses will be examined. Lastly, although no a priori hypotheses are reported, we will also examine gender differences between countries.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Interested participants will be directed to the online survey link that will contain the informed consent and screening questionnaire to determine eligibility. If eligible, participants will be automatically directed to a research questionnaire. Participation is expected to last no more than 45 minutes.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: On 3/16/2020 ASU's IRB reviewed and approved the protocol. Data collection in the US started on 3/18/2020 and is ongoing. Data collection in Italy started on 3/19/2020 and is ongoing. All other participating countries anticipate starting data collection by 4/15/2020.

question.value: Participants will be recruited by survey distribution on social media sites (e.g., Facebook) targeted to individuals living in the specific countries. Inclusion criteria are as follows: (1) over the age of 18 years, (2) living in the respective country, (3) in a romantic relationship for at least 1 year, and (4) living with one’s romantic partner.

attributes.title: The effect of gratitude on immoral behaviour
attributes.description: In a previous study, we found that gratitude promoted the beneficiary to lie for his or her benefactor. The relationship-building tendency and harm avoidance played roles in the gratitude-induced lying. Here we plan to test these findings by running a preregistered replication.

q2.value:
We plan to replicate the findings of our previous study:
1) Participants in the gratitude condition are more likely to lie to their boss for their benefactor than the control condition.
2) Participants in the gratitude condition are more inclined to build a friendship (friendship-building tendency) with their benefactor than the control condition.
3) Participants in the gratitude condition has stronger motivation to reduce their benefactor’ potential loss (harm avoidance) than the control condition.
4) The friendship-building tendency correlates with the harm avoidance.
5) The friendship-building tendency and harm avoidance play roles in the gratitude-induced lying.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
The design and procedure of this preregistered study will be the same as our previous study:
This is a between-subjects design with 1 factor (emotion) and 2 levels (gratitdue vs. control).

Participants were required to imagine that they were in a following scenario, which was revised from a vignette developed by Watkins et al. (2006):
Recently, you got a job in a new company and met a new colleague, A. You and A chatted together occasionally. One day, A asked you what you would be doing next Saturday. You said that you found a new apartment and would be spending the whole day moving. A volunteered to help you move. That Saturday, you saw A outside of your apartment early in the morning, ready to help. A helped you for most of the day until you completed your move. With the help of A, you saved lots of time and effort. Afterwards, you learned the reason why A offered to help.
In the control condition, participants read ‘A hoped that you could undertake some of their work in the future’. In the gratitude condition, participants read ‘Having experienced moving house alone, A knew how hard and tiring it was and did not want you to suffer’. The latter description of the intent of A’s helping behaviour proved to be efficient in inducing gratitude (Watkins et al., 2006). Afterwards, participants rated how much gratitude, shame, unhappiness, anger, indebtedness, and guilt they felt towards A, to what extent they thought A concerned for their benefits, to what extent they wanted to build a friendship with A, to what extent they thought a friendship with A would benefit them in the future, how much cost they thought A undertook for helping them, how much benefit they thought they received from A (1 = not at all, 9 = very much).
The participants then imagined the following situation and answered a series of questions:
Colleague A, who helped you move before, do not come to work on a Friday afternoon. You know that A is going hiking without leave. Your boss is very angry because of A’s absence and asks you why A is absent.

Moral violation (lying): How likely you are to lie to your boss in order to help A.
Harm avoidance: To what extent you want to reduce A’s potential losses when answering your boss’s question.
Moral judgment: To what extent A’s behaviour is immoral.
Moral principle: To what extent you concern for your own honesty when answering your boss’s question
Concerns for one’s own benefits: To what extent you concern for your own benefits when answering your boss’s question.

q7.value: Participants will complete the experiment online. The experimenter will randomly assign participants to one of the two different conditions by send one of the two links to the participants. She will not know which link is corresponding to which condition.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements posted on the BBS of our university. They will be paid 10 Chinese yuan for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years and don't have mental diseases. They will complete the experiment online. It takes them about 12 minutes.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 140 participants. Participants who do not pass an attention check will be excluded from the data analyses. We plan to recruit 140 valid participants, all of whom should pass the attention check.

q12.value: The main purpose of this preregistered study is to test whether we can replicate the effect of gratitude on lying. In our previous study, we found that the effect of gratitude on lying was f = 0.261. We set the probability of type I error (.05), expected effect size (f = .261), and power (1 － β = .80) and determined the minimum sample size to be 118 participants for this preregistered study. Thus, we plan to recruit 140 valid participants.

q13.value: The recruitment will stop when when we have 140 (valid) participants. Valid participants refer to those who pass the attention check.

question.value: We will manipulate the gratitdue emotion of participants by showing them two different scenarios (gratitude vs. control).

After reading the first episode of the scenario, participants will rate how much gratitude, shame, unhappiness, anger, indebtedness, and guilt they feel towards A, to what extent they think A concerns for their benefits, to what extent they want to build a friendship with A, to what extent they think a friendship with A would benefit them in the future, how much cost they think A undertake for helping them, how much benefit they think they receive from A (1 = not at all, 9 = very much).

After reading the second episode of the scenario, participants will answer a series of questions: Moral violation (lying): How likely you are to lie to your boss in order to help A. Harm avoidance: To what extent you want to reduce A’s potential losses when answering your boss’s question. Moral judgment: To what extent A’s behaviour is immoral. Moral principle: To what extent you concern for your own honesty when answering your boss’s question. Concerns for one’s own benefits: To what extent you concern for your own benefits when answering your boss’s question.

The analysis strategy will be the same as our previous study: We will use ANOVAs (between-subjects, two levels) to examine whether there are significant differences between the gratitude and control conditions in the gratitude rating, participants’ perception about A’s concern for their benefits, relationship-building tendency, relational utility, lying, harm avoidance, moral judgment, moral principle, and concerns for one’s own benefits. We will use ANOVAs to examine whether the gratitude rating is higher than any other emotion rating in the gratitude condition.

We will use the Pearson correlations to examine whether there is significant correlation between the relationship-building tendency and relational utility. We will use the Pearson correlations to examine whether there is significant correlation between the relationship-building tendency and harm avoidance (or moral judgment, moral principle, concerns for one’s own benefits).

We will use the simple mediation model to test whether relationship-building tendency mediates the effect of gratitude on lying. We will use the serial multiple mediation model to test whether relationship-building tendency and harm avoidance (or moral judgment, moral principle, concerns for one’s own benefits) mediate the effect of gratitude on lying in sequence, when the other psychological factors are entered as covariates. We will also use the serial multiple mediation model to test whether relationship-building tendency and harm avoidance mediate the effect of other emotions (i.e. shame, unhappiness, anger, indebtedness, or guilt) on lying in sequence (If significant effects are found, we will put the gratitude rating into the model as a covariate and conduct the serial multiple mediation analysis again).

I think the most important statistical analyses will be 1) whether the effect of gratitude on lying is significant (ANOVA), 2) whether the effect of gratitude on friendship-building tendency is significant (ANOVA), 3) whether the effect of gratitude on harm avoidance is significant (ANOVA), 4) whether the correlation between friendship-building tendency and harm avoidance is significant (Pearson correlation), 5) whether the indirect effect of gratitude on lying through relationship-building tendency and harm avoidance in sequence is significant (serial multiple mediation).

q19.value:
We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVAs and the Pearson correlation suggest that the results are significant or not (p < 0.1 will be considered as marginally significant). The effect of mediation will be considered as significnat if the 95% confidence interval does not cover 0. 

The Bonferroni correction will be used when we explore whether gratitdue effects harm avoidance, moral judgment, moral principle, or concerns for one’s own benefits. The Bonferroni correction will be used when we explore whether relationship-building tendency correlates with harm avoidance, moral judgment, moral principle, or concerns for one’s own benefits.

q20.value: Participants who do not pass an attention check or do not complete the experiment will be excluded from the analyses.

q21.value: Participants will complete the experiment online. There will not be missing data.

q23.value:
We plan to replicate our previous findings about the effect of gratitdue on lying by running a preregistered replication.

The sample size of the previous study was 127.

The effect sizes of the important findings of the previous study were:
1) The effect of gratitude on lying: partial η2 = .063.
2) The effect of gratitude on friendship-building tendency: partial η2 = .656.
3) The effect of gratitude on harm avoidance: partial η2 = .190.
4) The correlation between friendship-building tendency and harm avoidance: r = 0.51.
5) The indirect effect of gratitude on lying through relationship-building tendency and harm avoidance in sequence: β = 0.06.

2) Participants in the gratitude condition are more inclined to build a friendship (friendship-building tendency) with their benefactor than the control condition.
3) Participants in the gratitude condition has stronger motivation to reduce their benefactor’ potential loss (harm avoidance) than the control condition.
4) The friendship-building tendency correlates with the harm avoidance.
5) The friendship-building tendency and harm avoidance play roles in the gratitude-induced lying.
