attributes.title: The role of saliency and head movement in visual search - with Gabor patches
attributes.description: A study using a Gabor patch visual search paradigm in a 360 view VR headset and eye tracking. Not all Gabor patches are in the immediate field of view to facilitate exploration of more real world visual search.

q1.value: The role of saliency and head movement in visual search (Part 1 using Gabor patches)

q3.value: There is strong evidence that location is not well represented in peripheral vision. On the other hand, more salient objects can be better discriminated and are more likely to be fixated.  When we search for an object does its salience help guide the landing position of our eyes? Furthermore, it is not clear how objects are discriminated and localized in the periphery as they come into view due to head movement – does the process of detection and localization occur in the same way and is it similarly affected by salience? We test this in virtual reality using visual search for a vertical or horizontal Gabor patch that is salient or non-salient amongst other Gabor patches arranged in four clusters, two of which are visible either side of a fixation cross upon onset (termed near) or only come into view once moving the head, each far cluster being the same distance again as the near clusters (termed far).

q4.value:
H1 Salience increases detection speed
This would be shown by faster RT (measured by time to button press, first fixation on target, last fixation on target before button press) and faster RT from first appearance of target in the field of view (FoV) for salient than non-salient targets

H2 Salience improves landing accuracy 
This would be shown by fewer fixations within the target cluster, smaller distance between the first fixation within the target cluster and the target, higher % chance of moving eyes towards target cluster from fixation cross/neighbouring cluster for salient than non-salient targets

H3 Entering FoV vs  onset of  stimulus increases detection speed 
This would be shown faster RT from first appearance of target in FoV for far than near targets.  

H4 Entering FoV vs  onset of  stimulus increases improves accuracy 
This would be shown by fewer fixations within the target cluster, smaller distance between the first fixation within the target cluster and the target, higher % chance of moving eyes towards target cluster from fixation cross/neighbouring cluster for salient than non-salient targets for far than near targets.

H5 Entering FoV vs onset of  stimulus increases the effect of salience on detection speed 
This would be shown by a larger RT differences found for salience for far than near targets.

H6 Entering FoV vs onset of  stimulus increases the effect of salience on landing accuracy
This would be shown by a larger accuracy difference found for salience for far than near targets.

See  Methods attachment for further explanation of conditions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
2x2 repeated measures, with conditions- location (near/far) and salience (high/low)- analysed for each DV separately:
RT to button press
RT to last target fixation
RT to first target fixation
RT from first appearance of target in Field of View to first target fixation  
% chance of fixation going towards target from fixation cross/neighbouring cluster
Number of fixations within target cluster (before locating target)
Distance of first fixation within target cluster from target

q9.value: 5 blocks of pre-generated stimuli, in each of which the target appears in each cluster 5 times and can be horizontal or vertical and salient or not salient.  The locations of the Gabors are randomly chosen for each cluster from within a circular area of 45 deg across, such that the patches do not overlap and the target is randomly given one of the locations.  Each participant sees one of these blocks, pseudo randomly allocated.  Within each experiment the trials within the given block are randomized.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: Data was analysed to check how many participants we had once we applied our exclusion criteria.  We also created summary statistics for 17 participants - only of their button press reaction times in the separate conditions.

question.value: Participants were recruited from the department’s paid participant pool and paid £5 for taking part.  Participants must have normal or corrected to normal vision.

q14.value: This was based on achieving around 20 participants, which was around the upper end of number of participants used in past visual search type eye tracking studies.

question.value:
Near: target is found within the cluster of Gabor patches either to the left or right of the initial fixation cross (within clusters centred at 35 deg from fixation - see Methods attachment).
Far: target is found within cluster of Gabor patches either to the far left or right of the initial fixation cross (within clusters centred at 70 deg from fixation - see Methods attachment).
There are always 4 clusters present.
Salient: distractors are +/- 70 deg orientation from the target orientation (16 one way, 15 the other)
Non-salient: distractors are +/- 20 deg orientation from target orientation-   see Methods attachment.

For each person variables will be calculated from the mean of (non-excluded) repetitions from a trial (10 per cell, less if some trials have to be excluded).
RT to button press
RT to last target fixation
RT to first target fixation
RT from first appearance of target in Field of View to first fixation
% chance of fixation landing towards target from fixation cross/neighbouring cluster
Number of fixations within target cluster (before locating target)
Distance of first fixation within target cluster from target
	
See Methods attachment for further detail.

We will use two-way repeated measures ANOVA to analyze our results. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are location and salience whereas the dependent variables are RTs (time to button press, time to first fixation on target, time to last fixation on target, time to first fixation on target from appearance in field of view), % chance of correct eye movement direction from previous cluster/fixation cross, number of fixations within the target cluster and distance of initial fixation in target cluster from target. We will test the main effects and interactions to test our hypotheses for each of the dependent variables. Please see attached Methods for further explanation of terms.

q21.value: We will use the critical value p<0.05.  We will use two tail tests as the data can go either way. We will account for multiple DVs and conditions being tested by making sure that the differences found are considered within the full context of the other variables.

attributes.title: ‘If They Struggle, I Can’t Sleep Well Either’: The Interaction Between Student and Teacher Well-Being in Higher Education
attributes.description: In recent years, the topics of student well-being and teacher well-being have received more visibility in higher education research. While there are numerous studies that investigate well-being among students, and others that explore teacher well-being, it is often the case that they are researched in isolation from one another, despite being interconnected with the same university environment. In the present study we conduct semi-structured interviews to comprehensively investigate the interaction between student and teacher well-being. In doing this, we explore similarities and differences in how students and teachers define their perceptions of well-being at the university, and how the two overlap. Gaining knowledge about this topic is important for understanding how teachers and students can benefit from one another in terms of maintaining and fostering well-being in the university environment.

q1.value: Lisa Kiltz, E.P.W.A. Jansen, Raven Rinas, Martin Daumiller, Marjon Fokkens-Bruinsma

q2.value:
Research Questions: 
a) How do students and teachers differ in their perceptions and definitions of well-being at the university?
b) How do student and teacher well-being interact?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Semi-structured interviews were conducted. In the context of the present study, the interviews were structured to examine the perception of well-being from both parties and therefore cover both research questions. It should be noted that the interview questions focused on in the present study were selected from a larger interview (also conducted by the present researchers) containing more questions with a separate research goal. The sample comprises university students as well as teachers. The interviews were conducted at two different universities, one in Germany, and the other in the Netherlands.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Data was created within this project by the researchers. The registration, however, is only being submitted now. We are currently in the phase of finishing data collection. Moreover, most of the interviews are already transcribed. Still, data analysis has not yet begun.

question.value: The participants were recruited via already existing contacts. People involved in the project asked potential participants if they would be willing to take part in the study as well as if they themselves knew people who would want to. The interviews were held partly at the university and partly at the students’ homes, according to their preference. They took around 1-1,5 hours and were audio-recorded.

q11.value: Altogether sixteen interviews were conducted. 1) six university students 2) ten university teachers

q12.value: We wanted to have a relatively equal sample size of both students and teachers, arriving at our total sample size of six students and ten teachers.

question.value: Since this project uses qualitative research methods, there is no clear outcome variable, but only themes which emerge during the coding process and which could answer the research questions.

First, the interviews are transcribed. Then, the transcripts are initially coded according to the research questions. These codes emerged mainly from the data. As we are aware that the Self-Determination Theory represents a theoretical framework fitting for our purposes, so we kept it in mind while coding. All codes emerging within this initial coding phase are then categorized in overarching themes and codes and afterwards, the transcripts are recoded according to the resulting codebook. Another researcher from the research team uses the same codebook to code the transcript as well in order to check for inter-rater reliability. Beyond that, in-depth qualitative analysis will be carried out.

q22.value: The data is supposed to answer the research questions. Being qualitative in nature, the study generally answers these in an exploratory way. Further on, Self-Determination Theory with its basic psychological needs served as background for deductive coding.
